Best Practices in Cloud Computing: Implementation and Operational Implications for the Cloud Ruth Lennon 
Letterkenny Institute of Technology, Ireland Ruth.Lennon@LYIT.ie  Amir Zeid American University of Kuwait, 
Iraq Amir.Zeid@gmail.com  Lars Arne Skår Morten Udnæs Arne Jorgen Berre Miles Consulting, Miles Consulting, 
Sintef Norway Norway Norway Lars@miles.no Udnaes@miles.no Arne.j.berre@sintef.no Dumitru Roman Einar 
Landre Willem-Jan van den Heuvel STI, University of Innsbruck, StatoilHydro, European Research Institute 
in Austria Norway Services Science, dumitru.roman@sti2.at Einla@statoilhydro.com The Netherlands wjheuvel@uvt.nl 
 Abstract Many companies are now surfing the cloud in order to generate renewed interest in their companies. 
Buzzwords have increasingly gained importance in marketing of on-line services. In this poster researchers 
in educational and implementers in industry will work together to outline the major issues that are prevalent 
in the im­plementation of Cloud systems. The poster will be developed from the related workshop which 
investigates best practices as defined by both academia and industry.. Categories and Subject Descriptors 
D.2.0 [Software Engineer­ing]]: general -standards. D.2.2 [Design tools and techniques], D.2.3. [Coding 
tools and techniques], D.2.5. Testing and debug­ging, D.2.6. Programming Environments, D.2.9 Management, 
D.2.11 Software Architectures, D.2.12 Interoperability, De.2.13 Reusable Software.. General Terms: Management, 
Performance, Design, Economics, Reliability, Security, Human Factors, Standardization, Legal As­pects. 
Keywords Cloud; SOA; Web Services; Service Orientation; SaaS. 1. Introduction Cloud computing is shown 
itself as the next evolution of web services married with Grid computing. Moving from Grid to In­frastructure 
As A Services (IAAS) does not take much of a leap of imagination. Software As A Service (SAAS) is one 
of the more notable commercial successes of web services and also leads di­rectly to the development 
of cloud computing as a technique to Copyright is held by the author/owner(s). OOPSLA 2009, October 25-29, 
2009, Orlando, FL, USA. ACM 978-1-60558-768-4/09/10. provide IAAS. Without getting bogged down in acronyms 
it is clear to see where Cloud computing will most benefit enterprise. Due to the relatively recent development 
of cloud and it s speed of adoption by the commercial market it is clear at this stage that many issues 
have arisen that could have been avoided. Further it can be seen that some more serious issues need to 
be addressed very quickly if cloud computing is to continue to play a part in modern enterprise application 
development: This poster will outline the results of the related workshop. Due to the interactive nature 
of the workshop a number of ques­tions will be explored such as: will the move to Cloud based tech­nologies 
strengthen the arguments put forward by Nicholas G. Carr that IT doesn t matter ? The workshop will focus 
on the implementation and opera­tional issues surrounding the cloud and will provide summary of the comments 
and conclusions reached during the workshop. The balance of industrial to educational input in each issue 
will pro­vide a more balanced view and should result in interesting new topics for further discussion: 
 2. Organizers There are multiple organizers of the workshop from industry and academia. Organizers include:. 
 Ruth Lennon, Researcher & Lecturer in Letterkenny Institute of Technology, Ireland.  Lars Arne 
Skar, CTO of Miles Consulting based in Norway.  Morten Udnaes, Systems Architect, Miles Consulting, 
Norway.  Arne Berre, Chief Scientist in SINTEF ICT Research Unit.  Dr. Amir Zeid, is the program lead 
of Computer Science and Information Systems at the American University of Kuwait.  Dumitru Roman, Senior 
Researcher in Semantic Technology Institute, Innsbruck, Austria.   Einar Landre, is a practicing software 
professional with 25 years experience.  Prof. Dr. Willem­Jan van den Heuvel is the managing director 
of the European Research Institute of Services Science.  The organizers of the related workshop have 
produced this poster so as to provide a moderated and insightful summary of the views of the workshop 
participants. The poster may provide con­troversial opinions along with insightful comments on best prac­tice! 
3. Poster Format The poster will contain a number of sections which will outline what the participants 
expected from the workshop; the topics identified for discussion; survey results; participant comments; 
workshop conclusions and finally problems that were identified. The poster will include short terms or 
comments as made by the participants, gathered and organised by organisers into a co­herent format for 
presentation. As with last years workshop we would expect some of the comments to be controversial. Often 
it is in the need to convert a utopian albeit intangible solution to something more concrete for the 
commercial world that provides the most interesting steps towards new thinking. 4. Questions: Implications 
for the Cloud Some of the more concrete questions that it is envisaged will be discussed in this poster 
include: Is Cloud Computing a viable option for legacy mission critical backend systems typically supported 
by mainframes?  To save money and increase services levels, more and more communication between people 
and government services are carried out through the internet. Is Cloud Computing a suit­able platform 
for government self­services..  Will the move to Cloud based technologies strengthen the arguments put 
forward by Nicholas G. Carr that IT doesn t matter ?  Can Cloud Computing change the way we organize 
IT? Is there a need for an IT­department when all physical concepts like servers and networks are gone? 
 Has SOA been replaced by Cloud [1]?  Will SaaS be overshadowed by Cloud?  The final list of topics 
will be decided upon by the workshop members.  5. Comments Pay as you go has worked in the telephony 
market for many years and is now being adapted for software services on the internet. The releasing of 
hardware processing resources in such a manner has become a topic of much discussion. In fact NASA and 
a num­ber of research organizations have been utilizing home users un­used processing power for quite 
some time. The definition of what constitutes cloud computing is in itself somewhat vague [2] as the 
term Web 2.0 progresses to Web 3.0 without any significant change in technologies. Work on evaluating 
the need for and abil­ity of cloud computing has been discussed in [3] and defines some of the difficulties 
involved. Commercial applications such as Amazon s Elastic Compute Cloud (aws.amazon.com/ec2/), Sky-Tap, 
GridLayer and CohesiveFT stem from large organisations to smaller enterprises seizing a niche in the 
market. It is interesting to see that the commercial applications of Cloud runs from SAAS, IAAS, Platforms 
as a Service (PAAS), Storage services, monitor­ing services, modelling services and security services 
to name but a few. The issue of security services to run over the cloud is perhaps on of the most interesting. 
With the processing of data farmed out to unknown service providers the increasing need for tightened 
security is a must. Indeed it may be seen that the lack of trust and fear of security issues may provide 
the largest stumbling block to the acceptance of cloud based services. The poster provides a summary 
of the thoughts of both industry and academic represen­tatives on this and many other issues. 6. Summary 
A workshop on the implementation and operational implications of cloud using established and indeed innovative 
best practice techniques will explore the practical issues involved in the release of cloud systems to 
the market. The issues identified by the work­shop will be presented in a poster which will be available 
online as well as being displayed at OOPSLA 2009. The results of the workshop will be published on: https://wiki.miles.no/display/EXT/oopsla09_cloud_computing. 
 References [1] unknown author, SOA is dead; long live Services, aps­blog.burtongroup.com/2009/01/soa-is-dead-long-live-services.html 
[2] Vaquero, Luis M., Rodera-Merino, Luis, Caceres, Juan and Lindner Maik, A Break in the Clouds: Towards 
a Cloud Definition, SIG-COMM Computer Communication Review, ACM, Vol. 39, Issue 1, December 2008. [3] 
Napper, Jeffrey, Bientinesi, Paolo, Can Cloud Computing Reach the Top 500?, UCHPC-MAW 09, May 18-20, 
2009, Ischia, Italy.
